Why Kudobox?

20 Feb 2014

When I start doing a new product, the first question I answer is “Why do I need it?” This question is so important to me, because it determines the criteria of my happiness during a long period of the product’s life.

Great products are created by happy people. I must be happy in the first place to make one.

There's rarely just one reason why you start doing something. I found three major reasons "Why Kudobox?":

  1. I do want to create a product which makes a positive impact on people's lives
  2. I want to develop a product because I love developing products
  3. I want to have a product which brings me money and let me live wherever I wish

Both the reasons and their order are important to me.

I was on an startup ideation workshop several days ago and one speaker was talking about his success. He began his speech with a phrase "I'm going to tell you how to make products which will bring you a huge pile of money".  His talk was all about money. At the end he was asked what if his product harms people and he replied "Well, yeah, it's possible but I'll care about it when I become a billionaire". His approach is alien to me though I understand his position.

If you put money first, you must get them fast. Otherwise you won't be happy. Unfortunately, it's only possible if you make painkillers.

Kudobox doesn't help people to kill their pain. It helps them to start living a healthier and happier life.

And this path — the path of changing habits — is really long. You need something to be constantly motivated by. For me it's people's emotions when they receive kudos.
